sida:strategy.sida:title: Bangladesh 2021-2025
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Bangladesh 2021-2025

title.narrative: MJF: Stöd till civilsamhällsorganisationer i Bangl
MJF: Support for Civil Society Organizations in Ba

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Utvecklingsinsatsen utgörs av stöd till ett femårigt projekt med fokus på att stärka kapaciteten hos det bangladeshiska civilsamhällets aktörer, främst mindre organisationer och nätverk av mindre organisationer, verksamma på området jämställdhet (med fokus på förebyggande av våld mot kvinnor) mänskliga rättigheter och miljö och klimatrelaterade frågor (med fokus på stärkt resiliens på lokal nivå). Projektet skall genomföras av Manusher Jonno Foundation i samarbete med Bangladeshiska partnerorganisationer ur civilsamhället. Verksamhet omfattar ett flertal komponenter som syftar till kapacitetsutveckling av partners i civilsamhället, nätverksbyggande, påvekansarbete och finansiellt stöd till implementering av projekt som är relevanta för resultat. Särskilt tematiskt fokus inom insatsen ligger på för Sida prioriterade frågor inom god samhällsstyrning, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och miljö och klimat.
Det är Sidas bedömning att Manusher Jonno Foundation har en unik ställning bland bangladeshiska aktörer inom civilsamhället, genom sin långvariga erfarenhet av liknande typer av stöd, både med avseende på kapacitetsutveckling av och vidareförmedling av projektstöd till mindre civilsamhällsorganisationer i landet. Manusher Jonno har visat goda resultat i tidigare projekt med stöd av andra internationella givare och har goda förutsättningar att nå uppställda resultat även i detta projekt.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The development intervention consists of a five-year project focusing on strengthening the capacity of Bangladeshi civil society, mainly smaller organizations and networks of smaller organizations, active in the field of gender equality (with a focus on prevention of violence against women), human rights and environment and climate-related issues (with focus on strengthening resilience at the local level). The project will be implemented by Manusher Jonno Foundation in cooperation with Bangladeshi partner organizations from civil society. Activities include a variety of components aimed at capacity development of partners in civil society, networking, advocacy and financial support to the implementation of projects relevant to the results. The thematic focus of the intervention is on Sida’s priority issues in good governance, human rights, gender equality and environment and climate.
It is Sida's assessment that Manusher Jonno Foundation has a unique position among Bangladeshi actors in civil society, through its long-standing experience in similar types of support, both in terms of capacity development and forwarding of funds to small civil society organizations in the country. MJF has shown good results in previous projects with the support of international donors, and has the capacity to do so in this intervention as well.

The overarching objective of the intervention is to enhance the capacity of civil society and public institutions to address violence against women in the public and private domain and to build greater resilience of vulnerable communities to deal with climate change. The project is supported through Manusher Jonno Foundation and implemented by 17 local partner organizations, of which 9 are working mainly on building community resilience to climate change and its impacts and 8 on combating gender-based violence.

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.

13.b - Främja mekanismer för att höja förmågan till effektiv klimatrelaterad planering och förvaltning i de minst utvecklade länderna, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, ungdomar samt lokala och marginaliserade samhällen.

13.b - Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The project consists of four main components: i) combating gender-based violence (GBV) ii) building community resilience to climate change and its impacts iii) strengthening institutions to ensure responsiveness towards gender concerns including violence against women (VAW) and climate change iv) Knowledge management and capacity development of CSO's, NGO sector and ofMJF staff The annual report for the period 1 December 2019 to 30 November 2020 collectsinformation from the 17 partner organizations and provides an overview of projectactivities, number of beneficiaries and achievements in quantitative terms. It alsocontains an analysis of the qualitative impact of the project. The project has reached a total number of 23 506 beneficiaries, of which 10 370 through the GBV component and 13 136 under the resilience component. The project experienced disruptions to the implementation in the reporting period, due to the outbreak of Covid-19 and the Government-declared nationwide lockdown which ensued and lasted from 23 March to 30 May. During this period, MJF and its partners were working from home and adapted their operations to the extent that it was possible, e.g. through sharing information about WHO guidelines on health and hygiene to prevent spread of the virus and the importance of maintaining social distancing. MJF and its partner organizations also monitored the situation with regard to gender-based violence and child marriages, through telephone surveys. These confirmed what other studies have also shown, e.g. an increasing prevalence of domestic violence, exploitation and abuse after the outbreak of Covid-19. MJF and partners thus accelerated their advocacy and networking efforts to support the victims and survivors. Social support groups and women leaders have also been advocating for targeted food support and services for violence survivors, with the active support of project staff and MJF. Examples of results achieved under the GBV component include 113 stopped child marriages through direct community initiatives, such as community mediation, arbitration by the local authorities and counseling to parents. The majority of these were after the outbreak of the pandemic. 1770 child marriages were prevented in project areas where MJF partners were undertaking awareness-raising activities and counseling. This can be compared to the preceding reporting year when 58 child marriages were stopped and 526 prevented through project interventions. In the reporting period, 1487 cases of domestic violence were reported. Of these, 1046 cases could be resolved by community leaders, youth groups and women leaders engaged in the project. There were also 291 protest events against VAWG, rape and child marriage led by women leaders and social support group members at village and union level. Reportedly, female beneficiaries and women leaders are increasingly challenging gendered norms, belief in the inherent superiority of men, acceptability of violence as a means to resolve conflicts, and harmful customs such as child marriage and dowry. By engaging men and boys the project is gradually contributing to changing harmful norms, behaviours and attitudes among male community members. By preventing child marriages the project also contributes to avoiding detrimental long-term effects for girls in terms of education, health and reproductive rights, and lower intra-household decision-making power. Under the resilience and climate change component a rapid assessment revealed an average monthly income loss of BDT 5,000 in the first months of the Covid-19 pandemic and due to the tropical cyclone Amphan, which reached Bangladesh on 16 May 2020 and impacted on coastal project areas. 85% of the survey respondents reported that they faced intimate partner violence during the lockdown while others said that they had faced some form of domestic violence. When asked, 90% of the respondents who were victims of domestic violence reported that their husbands were the main abusers. The most common reason for domestic violence during the pandemic was due to the increased financial stress on the family. The project partners were maintaining communication with service providers, which resulted in the endorsement of 59 community-level plans by the local authorities in the reporting period. 257 action point in these plans were implemented by service providers, and included installment of a deep tube well by the Chittagong Hill Tracts' Regional Council which gave access to safe drinking water to 150 people living in the area, and the excavation of a 3 km canal in Bhola district which ensured access to water for irrigation during the dry period for more than 150 households. By promoting the use of locally available resources at a lower cost and climate-resilient techniques, trained farmers have become more empowered, especially female farmers. The trained farmers have increased their production, which is having additional benefits for the communities by contributing to the local economy, as well as to social cohesion and food security. An impact study showed that 82 % of beneficiaries reported average increase in monthly income of 2370 BDT since the start of the project, although income levels has been impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic and natural disasters like tropical cyclones Amphan, Fani, Bulbul and flooding. Under the strengthening of public institutions component partners implemented various social accountability tools, such as social audits, community scorecards and public hearings to increase transparency and accountability between duty-bearers and rights-holders and ensure good governance. 3207 beneficiaries were oriented on social accountability tools through, 59 institutions were monitored with these tools and 59 plans were developed to improve service delivery. Under the knowledge management and capacity development component, MJF has provided capacity support to the 17 partner organizations and developed awareness-raising and information material. Examples include dissemination of information about Covid-19 protocols, such as social distancing, and health and hygiene safety. MJF and partners increased its efforts on advocacy to change the mindset of policymakers and targeted stakeholders by developing and disseminating a docudrama about the importance of stopping child marriages and the importance of engaging men and boys. A leaflet on National Emergency Helplines was also published to ensure prompt services towards survivors of violence against women and children during the pandemic. The leaflet was widely disseminated among beneficiaries, different stakeholders, and community people.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Verksamhet omfattar ett flertal komponenter som syftar till kapacitetsutveckling av partners i civilsamhället, nätverksbyggande, påvekansarbete och finansiellt stöd till implementering av projekt som är relevanta för resultat. Särskilt tematiskt fokus inom insatsen ligger på för Sida prioriterade frågor inom god samhällsstyrning, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet och miljö och klimat.
Det är Sidas bedömning att Manusher Jonno Foundation har en unik ställning bland bangladeshiska aktörer inom civilsamhället, genom sin långvariga erfarenhet av liknande typer av stöd, både med avseende på kapacitetsutveckling av och vidareförmedling av projektstöd till mindre civilsamhällsorganisationer i landet. Manusher Jonno har visat goda resultat i tidigare projekt med stöd av andra internationella givare och har goda förutsättningar att nå uppställda resultat även i detta projekt.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The development intervention consists of a five-year project focusing on strengthening the capacity of Bangladeshi civil society, mainly smaller organizations and networks of smaller organizations, active in the field of gender equality (with a focus on prevention of violence against women), human rights and environment and climate-related issues (with focus on strengthening resilience at the local level). The project will be implemented by Manusher Jonno Foundation in cooperation with Bangladeshi partner organizations from civil society. Activities include a variety of components aimed at capacity development of partners in civil society, networking, advocacy and financial support to the implementation of projects relevant to the results. The thematic focus of the intervention is on Sida’s priority issues in good governance, human rights, gender equality and environment and climate.
It is Sida's assessment that Manusher Jonno Foundation has a unique position among Bangladeshi actors in civil society, through its long-standing experience in similar types of support, both in terms of capacity development and forwarding of funds to small civil society organizations in the country. MJF has shown good results in previous projects with the support of international donors, and has the capacity to do so in this intervention as well.

The overarching objective of the intervention is to enhance the capacity of civil society and public institutions to address violence against women in the public and private domain and to build greater resilience of vulnerable communities to deal with climate change. The project is supported through Manusher Jonno Foundation and implemented by 17 local partner organizations, of which 9 are working mainly on building community resilience to climate change and its impacts and 8 on combating gender-based violence.

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.

13.b - Främja mekanismer för att höja förmågan till effektiv klimatrelaterad planering och förvaltning i de minst utvecklade länderna, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, ungdomar samt lokala och marginaliserade samhällen.

13.b - Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The project consists of four main components: i) combating gender-based violence (GBV) ii) building community resilience to climate change and its impacts iii) strengthening institutions to ensure responsiveness towards gender concerns including violence against women (VAW) and climate change iv) Knowledge management and capacity development of CSO's, NGO sector and ofMJF staff The annual report for the period 1 December 2019 to 30 November 2020 collectsinformation from the 17 partner organizations and provides an overview of projectactivities, number of beneficiaries and achievements in quantitative terms. It alsocontains an analysis of the qualitative impact of the project. The project has reached a total number of 23 506 beneficiaries, of which 10 370 through the GBV component and 13 136 under the resilience component. The project experienced disruptions to the implementation in the reporting period, due to the outbreak of Covid-19 and the Government-declared nationwide lockdown which ensued and lasted from 23 March to 30 May. During this period, MJF and its partners were working from home and adapted their operations to the extent that it was possible, e.g. through sharing information about WHO guidelines on health and hygiene to prevent spread of the virus and the importance of maintaining social distancing. MJF and its partner organizations also monitored the situation with regard to gender-based violence and child marriages, through telephone surveys. These confirmed what other studies have also shown, e.g. an increasing prevalence of domestic violence, exploitation and abuse after the outbreak of Covid-19. MJF and partners thus accelerated their advocacy and networking efforts to support the victims and survivors. Social support groups and women leaders have also been advocating for targeted food support and services for violence survivors, with the active support of project staff and MJF. Examples of results achieved under the GBV component include 113 stopped child marriages through direct community initiatives, such as community mediation, arbitration by the local authorities and counseling to parents. The majority of these were after the outbreak of the pandemic. 1770 child marriages were prevented in project areas where MJF partners were undertaking awareness-raising activities and counseling. This can be compared to the preceding reporting year when 58 child marriages were stopped and 526 prevented through project interventions. In the reporting period, 1487 cases of domestic violence were reported. Of these, 1046 cases could be resolved by community leaders, youth groups and women leaders engaged in the project. There were also 291 protest events against VAWG, rape and child marriage led by women leaders and social support group members at village and union level. Reportedly, female beneficiaries and women leaders are increasingly challenging gendered norms, belief in the inherent superiority of men, acceptability of violence as a means to resolve conflicts, and harmful customs such as child marriage and dowry. By engaging men and boys the project is gradually contributing to changing harmful norms, behaviours and attitudes among male community members. By preventing child marriages the project also contributes to avoiding detrimental long-term effects for girls in terms of education, health and reproductive rights, and lower intra-household decision-making power. Under the resilience and climate change component a rapid assessment revealed an average monthly income loss of BDT 5,000 in the first months of the Covid-19 pandemic and due to the tropical cyclone Amphan, which reached Bangladesh on 16 May 2020 and impacted on coastal project areas. 85% of the survey respondents reported that they faced intimate partner violence during the lockdown while others said that they had faced some form of domestic violence. When asked, 90% of the respondents who were victims of domestic violence reported that their husbands were the main abusers. The most common reason for domestic violence during the pandemic was due to the increased financial stress on the family. The project partners were maintaining communication with service providers, which resulted in the endorsement of 59 community-level plans by the local authorities in the reporting period. 257 action point in these plans were implemented by service providers, and included installment of a deep tube well by the Chittagong Hill Tracts' Regional Council which gave access to safe drinking water to 150 people living in the area, and the excavation of a 3 km canal in Bhola district which ensured access to water for irrigation during the dry period for more than 150 households. By promoting the use of locally available resources at a lower cost and climate-resilient techniques, trained farmers have become more empowered, especially female farmers. The trained farmers have increased their production, which is having additional benefits for the communities by contributing to the local economy, as well as to social cohesion and food security. An impact study showed that 82 % of beneficiaries reported average increase in monthly income of 2370 BDT since the start of the project, although income levels has been impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic and natural disasters like tropical cyclones Amphan, Fani, Bulbul and flooding. Under the strengthening of public institutions component partners implemented various social accountability tools, such as social audits, community scorecards and public hearings to increase transparency and accountability between duty-bearers and rights-holders and ensure good governance. 3207 beneficiaries were oriented on social accountability tools through, 59 institutions were monitored with these tools and 59 plans were developed to improve service delivery. Under the knowledge management and capacity development component, MJF has provided capacity support to the 17 partner organizations and developed awareness-raising and information material. Examples include dissemination of information about Covid-19 protocols, such as social distancing, and health and hygiene safety. MJF and partners increased its efforts on advocacy to change the mindset of policymakers and targeted stakeholders by developing and disseminating a docudrama about the importance of stopping child marriages and the importance of engaging men and boys. A leaflet on National Emergency Helplines was also published to ensure prompt services towards survivors of violence against women and children during the pandemic. The leaflet was widely disseminated among beneficiaries, different stakeholders, and community people.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Bangladesh 2021-2025
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Bangladesh 2021-2025

description.narrative: New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The project aims at strengthening urban health systems with focus on structural reform, coordination and partnerships at the national level. This proposal, in partnership with the Government of Bangladesh, Government of Sweden and UNICEF, represents a step towards sustainable urban PHC programming for quality health services, especially for the poorest and most vulnerable urban population. The proposed four years ( 2019-2023) of technical assistance from UNICEF will focus on the following results to be achieved by 2023: 1. Health systems are strengthened through institutional reform for functioning institutional structure and data management system to improve accountability for delivery of efficient Primary Health Care (PHC); 2. Innovative model of sustainable service delivery is established to improve access to and utilization of PHC services including standard minimum package of nutrition interventions especially by the poorest and most vulnerable population;3. Improved coverage of PHC in urban slum settlements and for socially segregated groups;4. Evidence on good practices and lessons learned is available for policy dialogue and advocacy to influence decision making processes.One of the most important features of this project is that it benefit 845,000 slum and non slum poor and low income population will benefit from the direct provision of primary health care services in the project areas. This will be achieved through a combination of efforts mix of a balance between upstream policy dialogue and advocacy and downstream work.PHC services will be strengthened through introduction of financial risk protection scheme which will improve the use and coverage of health services by women and children amongst vulnerable populations especially living in slum areas will increase. This will contribute towards improving demand, access and use of quality Maternal Newborn Child and Health services from vulnerable and underserved areas, and ultimately their rights to health care and survival is fulfilled;This will lead to the Innovative model of sustainable service delivery is established to improve access to and utilization of PHC services including standard minimum package of nutrition interventions especially by the poorest and most vulnerable/segregated population;Financial Protection mechanism through group health insurance mechanisms for low income and socially segregated populations will empower to benefit from quality PHC services close to their place of residence. Ultimately these vulnerable and socially segregated populations will experience fewer financial barriers to access life-saving PHC services;This will lead to the expected Objective 3: Improved coverage of PHC in urban slum settlements and for socially segregated groups;The improved governance system of urban health programs will contribute to improving coordination, measuring progress and accountability of urban health service delivery by the primary stakeholders, namely Ministry of Local Government , Ministry of Health and Local Government Institutions. Ultimately the urban population, especially from underserved areas, will realize their rights to health care and well-being.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Projektet syftar till att stärka urbana hälsosystem med fokus på strukturreformer, samordning och partnerskap på nationell nivå. Denna insats som genomförs i samarbete med regeringen i Bangladesh, Sverige och UNICEF, representerar ett steg mot hållbar primärvårdsplanering och service av god kvalitet, särskilt för den fattigaste och mest utsatta delen av befolkningen i urbana områden.
De föreslagna fyra åren (2019-2023) av stöd från UNICEF kommer att fokusera på följande resultat som ska uppnås före 2023: 1. Hälsosystemen stärks genom institutionell reform för en fungerande institutionell struktur och system för datahantering för att förbättra ansvaret för en effektiv primärhälsovård. 2. En innovativ modell för hållbar service upprättas för att förbättra tillgången till och utnyttjandet av primärhälsovård inklusive standardiserade baspaket för nutrition, särskilt för den fattigaste och mest utsatta befolkningen. 3. Förbättrad täckning av primärhälsovård i tätbebyggelse och för socialt segregerade grupper. 4. Evidens på god praxis och lärdomar finns tillgängliga för politisk dialog och för att påverka beslutsprocesser.
Insatsen ska nå 845 000 människor som lever i fattigdom i slumområden eller i andra urbana områden med låg inkomst och som direkt kommer att dra nytta av primärhälsovården. Primärvården avser nå: 1. 45 942 gravida kvinnor för vård vid graviditet och efter förlossning samt förlossningar på vårdinrättning av 32 816 kvinnor 2. 45.942 mödrar till nyfödda får grundläggande vård, 3. 45 492 mödrar får rådgivning om nutrition för mödrar, nyfödda och små barn 4. Vaccinationsprogram till 58 123 barn, genom spårning och kartläggning 5. 20 000 hushåll, ca 100 000 personer, kommer att informeras och uppmuntras att anmäla sig till ett system för grupphälsoförsäkring. 6. 12 000 textilarbetare ska nås av Mother @ Works programmet för att förbättra deras hälso- och näringsstatus samt immunisering. 7. Projektet kommer att bygga upp kapacitet för totalt 540 anställda från nationella till operativa nivåer: (nationella politiska beslutsfattare, hälsovårdsansvariga, leverantörer av hälsovård, sjukvårdspersonal, statsanställda inom vården, kommunala institutioner, icke-statliga organisationer och privat sektor).
Detta ska att uppnås genom en kombination och en balans mellan politisk dialog och påverkansarbete samt utformning av och implementering av vårdprogram.
Primärhälsovården kommer att stärkas genom införandet av ett system för finansiell riskskydd för förbättrad användning och täckning av hälsovård för kvinnor och barn inom utsatta grupper, särskilt de som bor i slumområden. Detta ska bidra till att förbättra efterfrågan, tillgång och användning av kvalitetsservice av mödra- och neonatalvård i marginaliserade områden, och i slutändan uppfylla deras rättigheter till hälsovård och överlevnad. Detta kommer att leda till att en innovativ modell för hållbar service utformas för att förbättra tillgången till och utnyttjandet av primärhälsovård inklusive standardminimipaket för nutrition, särskilt för den fattigaste och mest marginaliserade befolkningen;
En ekonomisk skyddsmekanism genom en grupphälsoförsäkring för låginkomsttagare och socialt segregerade grupper förväntas ge möjlighet till primärhälsovård av kvalitet nära bostaden. I slutändan kommer dessa utsatta och socialt segregerade grupper att ha färre ekonomiska hinder för tillgång till livräddande primärhälsovård; Detta kommer att leda till det förväntade mål 3: Förbättrad täckning av primärhälsovård i tätbebyggelse och för socialt segregerade grupper;
En effektiv policydialog baserad på god praxis och lärdomar från projekt, innovationer och följeforskning, förväntas bidra till engagemang och samordning mellan olika sektorer och avdelningar för en urban primärhälsovård i Bangladesh.
Ett förbättrat styrsystem för urbana hälsoprogram förväntas bidra till att förbättra samordningen, mäta framsteg och ansvarsskyldighet för urban primärvård av de främsta intressenterna, nämligen ministeriet för kommunala frågor, hälsovårdsministeriet och kommunala institutioner. I slutändan kommer stadsbefolkningen, särskilt från marginaliserad områden, bli medvetna om sina rättigheter till hälsovård och välbefinnande.

The overall vision of success for this project is that by 2023, sustainable improvement in the health status of the Bangladeshi population in urban areas is achieved, particularly for the poorest and most vulnerable groups. This will encompass strengthening institutional governance for sustainable delivery of Primary Health Care for women and children amongst the vulnerable population in underserved areas, particularly in urban slums and newly included wards in city corporations and municipalities. The four expected outcomes are: 1. Health systems are strengthened through institutional reform with a functioning institutional structure and data management systems to improve accountability for delivery of efficient Primary Health Care (PHC);2. Innovative model of sustainable service delivery system is established to improve access to and utilization of PHC services especially by the poorest and vulnerable/segregated population ;3. Coverage of primary health care is improved in urban slum settlements and for socially segregated groups4. Evidence based on good practices and lessons learned is available for policy dialogue and advocacy to influence decision making processes

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

description.narrative: UNICEF launched “Strengthening Urban Health Systems for Comprehensive Primary Health Care (PHC) for the Most Deprived Women and Children” with support from SIDA from 1st August 2019 to 31st August 2023. The project aimed to develop a sustainable urban PHC model for quality health services, especially for the poorest and most vulnerable urban population. The novel COVID-19 pandemic has created global havoc. Bangladesh had its first COVID-19 case on 8 March 2020. UNICEF was actively engaged in developing and revising the national COVID-19 response plan which is called BPRP (Bangladesh Preparedness and Response Plan), in collaboration with sister UN agencies and the wider development partner agencies. UNICEF also leveraged its financial and technical support through different pillar groups and technical committees formed by the DGHS as part of the COVID-19 response. Due to emergency response, to combat COVID-19 outbreak in the country, UNICEF postponed non-critical routine activities and reprogrammed some resources to support the emergency response of the MOHFW (BPRP). Against this backdrop, many of the planned project activities were either reprogrammed or re-purposed and some of the activities were postponed or deferred and most of the staff along with available resources were diverted to support the on-going COVID-19 Response Plan of the MOHFW. The on-going pandemic has also led to delayed execution of some of the activities planned for quarter 1 and 2. Amid the pandemic context, UNICEF - in consultation with the donor - carefully reviewed the activities of this project and re-programmed some of the non-essential activities to support the COVID-19 Response Plan. Despite of the COVID 19 outbreak the project has achieved several results which are stated below. UNICEF organized an assessment of urban health governance structure, existing policy and strategy framework, stakeholders mapping, existing service availability and health care seeking behaviour and vulnerability profile of population analysis. This assessment will inform the project’s focus for the urban primary health care strengthening and final report is expected by October 2020, delayed by 6 months due to difficulty in data collection amid the COVID-19 situation. However, the initial report by the consultants gave an assessment of urban health governance structure based on desk review. A roadmap was developed for strengthening existing Government led DHIS2 based Health Management Information Systems (HMIS), integrating NGO and private sector HMIS with national health information system and shared with Director MIS and Director Hospital Service Management of DGHS. Additional technical assistance was provided to the HMIS unit of DGHS to implement the roadmap for urban HMIS and to support both the routine and COVID-19 pandemic related HMIS data since the 15th of April 2020in the urban city-corporations and municipalities. One of the major achievements during the reporting period was the development of the draft urban PHC service delivery model - particularly targeting the vulnerable population in urban slums and non-slum areas. The draft PHC model was developed through a consultative process, which engaged all the stakeholders - including the urban Health Experts, Academia, Government Officials of different Ministries, urban health partners and NGO Service Managers. The model is now under review by the MOHFW for its finalization and implementation through a sustainable system approach - engaging MOHFW, MOLGRD, LGIs, DGHS and other partners. Although the model was supposed to be implemented during the 2nd quarter of this year it was delayed due to the ongoing pandemic situation. The baseline census of 40,000 HH was initiated in February 2020. The interventions to improve access to quality essential maternal, infant and young child nutrition and maternal and child health services among working women at the selected ready-made garment (RMG) factories implementing Mothers@Work programme has been focusing on building capacity of the RMG stakeholders during this reporting period. Capacity building materials have been prepared; however, the orientation and training of the stakeholders in the selected factories had been rescheduled to Q4 of 2020, due to the closure of the factories amid the COVID-19 pandemic. CoVID 19 related activities Sweden repurposed budget for CoVid 19 was primarily for Infection Prevention Control related supplies and activities. Funds were used for the procurement of the Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), following an urgent request from the MOHFW amid the shortage of PPE supplies to the facilities for the protection of the frontline health workers during the initial period of COVID-19 response. UNICEF responded promptly to the MOHFW’s urgent request of PPEs and other logistics through its global procurement services. Additional funds were availed principally for ‘Risk Communication and Community Engagement’ as a nation-wide initiative with attention to the Urban Areas. IEC material, Public Service Announcements and other communication materials were developed. It also supported the Risk Communication component of the Government’s COVID-19 response plan, District Information Officers were involved in the dissemination of the messages on preventive measures including personal hygiene and protection, social distancing of general people, and reaching vulnerable groups. In addition, these messages were broadcasted through the social media platform and television channels in the form of infographic and animation videos on benefits of staying home, adolescent nutrition and maternal nutrition. About 3.6 million people were reached.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

I slutändan kommer dessa utsatta och socialt segregerade grupper att ha färre ekonomiska hinder för tillgång till livräddande primärhälsovård; Detta kommer att leda till det förväntade mål 3: Förbättrad täckning av primärhälsovård i tätbebyggelse och för socialt segregerade grupper;
En effektiv policydialog baserad på god praxis och lärdomar från projekt, innovationer och följeforskning, förväntas bidra till engagemang och samordning mellan olika sektorer och avdelningar för en urban primärhälsovård i Bangladesh.
Ett förbättrat styrsystem för urbana hälsoprogram förväntas bidra till att förbättra samordningen, mäta framsteg och ansvarsskyldighet för urban primärvård av de främsta intressenterna, nämligen ministeriet för kommunala frågor, hälsovårdsministeriet och kommunala institutioner. I slutändan kommer stadsbefolkningen, särskilt från marginaliserad områden, bli medvetna om sina rättigheter till hälsovård och välbefinnande.

The overall vision of success for this project is that by 2023, sustainable improvement in the health status of the Bangladeshi population in urban areas is achieved, particularly for the poorest and most vulnerable groups. This will encompass strengthening institutional governance for sustainable delivery of Primary Health Care for women and children amongst the vulnerable population in underserved areas, particularly in urban slums and newly included wards in city corporations and municipalities. The four expected outcomes are: 1. Health systems are strengthened through institutional reform with a functioning institutional structure and data management systems to improve accountability for delivery of efficient Primary Health Care (PHC);2. Innovative model of sustainable service delivery system is established to improve access to and utilization of PHC services especially by the poorest and vulnerable/segregated population ;3. Coverage of primary health care is improved in urban slum settlements and for socially segregated groups4. Evidence based on good practices and lessons learned is available for policy dialogue and advocacy to influence decision making processes

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

description.narrative: UNICEF launched “Strengthening Urban Health Systems for Comprehensive Primary Health Care (PHC) for the Most Deprived Women and Children” with support from SIDA from 1st August 2019 to 31st August 2023. The project aimed to develop a sustainable urban PHC model for quality health services, especially for the poorest and most vulnerable urban population. The novel COVID-19 pandemic has created global havoc. Bangladesh had its first COVID-19 case on 8 March 2020. UNICEF was actively engaged in developing and revising the national COVID-19 response plan which is called BPRP (Bangladesh Preparedness and Response Plan), in collaboration with sister UN agencies and the wider development partner agencies. UNICEF also leveraged its financial and technical support through different pillar groups and technical committees formed by the DGHS as part of the COVID-19 response. Due to emergency response, to combat COVID-19 outbreak in the country, UNICEF postponed non-critical routine activities and reprogrammed some resources to support the emergency response of the MOHFW (BPRP). Against this backdrop, many of the planned project activities were either reprogrammed or re-purposed and some of the activities were postponed or deferred and most of the staff along with available resources were diverted to support the on-going COVID-19 Response Plan of the MOHFW. The on-going pandemic has also led to delayed execution of some of the activities planned for quarter 1 and 2. Amid the pandemic context, UNICEF - in consultation with the donor - carefully reviewed the activities of this project and re-programmed some of the non-essential activities to support the COVID-19 Response Plan. Despite of the COVID 19 outbreak the project has achieved several results which are stated below. UNICEF organized an assessment of urban health governance structure, existing policy and strategy framework, stakeholders mapping, existing service availability and health care seeking behaviour and vulnerability profile of population analysis. This assessment will inform the project’s focus for the urban primary health care strengthening and final report is expected by October 2020, delayed by 6 months due to difficulty in data collection amid the COVID-19 situation. However, the initial report by the consultants gave an assessment of urban health governance structure based on desk review. A roadmap was developed for strengthening existing Government led DHIS2 based Health Management Information Systems (HMIS), integrating NGO and private sector HMIS with national health information system and shared with Director MIS and Director Hospital Service Management of DGHS. Additional technical assistance was provided to the HMIS unit of DGHS to implement the roadmap for urban HMIS and to support both the routine and COVID-19 pandemic related HMIS data since the 15th of April 2020in the urban city-corporations and municipalities. One of the major achievements during the reporting period was the development of the draft urban PHC service delivery model - particularly targeting the vulnerable population in urban slums and non-slum areas. The draft PHC model was developed through a consultative process, which engaged all the stakeholders - including the urban Health Experts, Academia, Government Officials of different Ministries, urban health partners and NGO Service Managers. The model is now under review by the MOHFW for its finalization and implementation through a sustainable system approach - engaging MOHFW, MOLGRD, LGIs, DGHS and other partners. Although the model was supposed to be implemented during the 2nd quarter of this year it was delayed due to the ongoing pandemic situation. The baseline census of 40,000 HH was initiated in February 2020. The interventions to improve access to quality essential maternal, infant and young child nutrition and maternal and child health services among working women at the selected ready-made garment (RMG) factories implementing Mothers@Work programme has been focusing on building capacity of the RMG stakeholders during this reporting period. Capacity building materials have been prepared; however, the orientation and training of the stakeholders in the selected factories had been rescheduled to Q4 of 2020, due to the closure of the factories amid the COVID-19 pandemic. CoVID 19 related activities Sweden repurposed budget for CoVid 19 was primarily for Infection Prevention Control related supplies and activities. Funds were used for the procurement of the Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), following an urgent request from the MOHFW amid the shortage of PPE supplies to the facilities for the protection of the frontline health workers during the initial period of COVID-19 response. UNICEF responded promptly to the MOHFW’s urgent request of PPEs and other logistics through its global procurement services. Additional funds were availed principally for ‘Risk Communication and Community Engagement’ as a nation-wide initiative with attention to the Urban Areas. IEC material, Public Service Announcements and other communication materials were developed. It also supported the Risk Communication component of the Government’s COVID-19 response plan, District Information Officers were involved in the dissemination of the messages on preventive measures including personal hygiene and protection, social distancing of general people, and reaching vulnerable groups. In addition, these messages were broadcasted through the social media platform and television channels in the form of infographic and animation videos on benefits of staying home, adolescent nutrition and maternal nutrition. About 3.6 million people were reached.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Bangladesh 2014-2020
sida:strategy.sida:titleSV: Bangladesh 2014-2020

description.narrative: New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The project aims at strengthening urban health systems with focus on structural reform, coordination and partnerships at the national level. This proposal, in partnership with the Government of Bangladesh, Government of Sweden and UNICEF, represents a step towards sustainable urban PHC programming for quality health services, especially for the poorest and most vulnerable urban population. The proposed four years ( 2019-2023) of technical assistance from UNICEF will focus on the following results to be achieved by 2023: 1. Health systems are strengthened through institutional reform for functioning institutional structure and data management system to improve accountability for delivery of efficient Primary Health Care (PHC); 2. Innovative model of sustainable service delivery is established to improve access to and utilization of PHC services including standard minimum package of nutrition interventions especially by the poorest and most vulnerable population;3. Improved coverage of PHC in urban slum settlements and for socially segregated groups;4. Evidence on good practices and lessons learned is available for policy dialogue and advocacy to influence decision making processes.One of the most important features of this project is that it benefit 845,000 slum and non slum poor and low income population will benefit from the direct provision of primary health care services in the project areas. This will be achieved through a combination of efforts mix of a balance between upstream policy dialogue and advocacy and downstream work.PHC services will be strengthened through introduction of financial risk protection scheme which will improve the use and coverage of health services by women and children amongst vulnerable populations especially living in slum areas will increase. This will contribute towards improving demand, access and use of quality Maternal Newborn Child and Health services from vulnerable and underserved areas, and ultimately their rights to health care and survival is fulfilled;This will lead to the Innovative model of sustainable service delivery is established to improve access to and utilization of PHC services including standard minimum package of nutrition interventions especially by the poorest and most vulnerable/segregated population;Financial Protection mechanism through group health insurance mechanisms for low income and socially segregated populations will empower to benefit from quality PHC services close to their place of residence. Ultimately these vulnerable and socially segregated populations will experience fewer financial barriers to access life-saving PHC services;This will lead to the expected Objective 3: Improved coverage of PHC in urban slum settlements and for socially segregated groups;The improved governance system of urban health programs will contribute to improving coordination, measuring progress and accountability of urban health service delivery by the primary stakeholders, namely Ministry of Local Government , Ministry of Health and Local Government Institutions. Ultimately the urban population, especially from underserved areas, will realize their rights to health care and well-being.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Projektet syftar till att stärka urbana hälsosystem med fokus på strukturreformer, samordning och partnerskap på nationell nivå. Denna insats som genomförs i samarbete med regeringen i Bangladesh, Sverige och UNICEF, representerar ett steg mot hållbar primärvårdsplanering och service av god kvalitet, särskilt för den fattigaste och mest utsatta delen av befolkningen i urbana områden.
De föreslagna fyra åren (2019-2023) av stöd från UNICEF kommer att fokusera på följande resultat som ska uppnås före 2023: 1. Hälsosystemen stärks genom institutionell reform för en fungerande institutionell struktur och system för datahantering för att förbättra ansvaret för en effektiv primärhälsovård. 2. En innovativ modell för hållbar service upprättas för att förbättra tillgången till och utnyttjandet av primärhälsovård inklusive standardiserade baspaket för nutrition, särskilt för den fattigaste och mest utsatta befolkningen. 3. Förbättrad täckning av primärhälsovård i tätbebyggelse och för socialt segregerade grupper. 4. Evidens på god praxis och lärdomar finns tillgängliga för politisk dialog och för att påverka beslutsprocesser.
Insatsen ska nå 845 000 människor som lever i fattigdom i slumområden eller i andra urbana områden med låg inkomst och som direkt kommer att dra nytta av primärhälsovården. Primärvården avser nå: 1. 45 942 gravida kvinnor för vård vid graviditet och efter förlossning samt förlossningar på vårdinrättning av 32 816 kvinnor 2. 45.942 mödrar till nyfödda får grundläggande vård, 3. 45 492 mödrar får rådgivning om nutrition för mödrar, nyfödda och små barn 4. Vaccinationsprogram till 58 123 barn, genom spårning och kartläggning 5. 20 000 hushåll, ca 100 000 personer, kommer att informeras och uppmuntras att anmäla sig till ett system för grupphälsoförsäkring. 6. 12 000 textilarbetare ska nås av Mother @ Works programmet för att förbättra deras hälso- och näringsstatus samt immunisering. 7. Projektet kommer att bygga upp kapacitet för totalt 540 anställda från nationella till operativa nivåer: (nationella politiska beslutsfattare, hälsovårdsansvariga, leverantörer av hälsovård, sjukvårdspersonal, statsanställda inom vården, kommunala institutioner, icke-statliga organisationer och privat sektor).
Detta ska att uppnås genom en kombination och en balans mellan politisk dialog och påverkansarbete samt utformning av och implementering av vårdprogram.
Primärhälsovården kommer att stärkas genom införandet av ett system för finansiell riskskydd för förbättrad användning och täckning av hälsovård för kvinnor och barn inom utsatta grupper, särskilt de som bor i slumområden. Detta ska bidra till att förbättra efterfrågan, tillgång och användning av kvalitetsservice av mödra- och neonatalvård i marginaliserade områden, och i slutändan uppfylla deras rättigheter till hälsovård och överlevnad. Detta kommer att leda till att en innovativ modell för hållbar service utformas för att förbättra tillgången till och utnyttjandet av primärhälsovård inklusive standardminimipaket för nutrition, särskilt för den fattigaste och mest marginaliserade befolkningen;
En ekonomisk skyddsmekanism genom en grupphälsoförsäkring för låginkomsttagare och socialt segregerade grupper förväntas ge möjlighet till primärhälsovård av kvalitet nära bostaden. I slutändan kommer dessa utsatta och socialt segregerade grupper att ha färre ekonomiska hinder för tillgång till livräddande primärhälsovård; Detta kommer att leda till det förväntade mål 3: Förbättrad täckning av primärhälsovård i tätbebyggelse och för socialt segregerade grupper;
En effektiv policydialog baserad på god praxis och lärdomar från projekt, innovationer och följeforskning, förväntas bidra till engagemang och samordning mellan olika sektorer och avdelningar för en urban primärhälsovård i Bangladesh.
Ett förbättrat styrsystem för urbana hälsoprogram förväntas bidra till att förbättra samordningen, mäta framsteg och ansvarsskyldighet för urban primärvård av de främsta intressenterna, nämligen ministeriet för kommunala frågor, hälsovårdsministeriet och kommunala institutioner. I slutändan kommer stadsbefolkningen, särskilt från marginaliserad områden, bli medvetna om sina rättigheter till hälsovård och välbefinnande.

The overall vision of success for this project is that by 2023, sustainable improvement in the health status of the Bangladeshi population in urban areas is achieved, particularly for the poorest and most vulnerable groups. This will encompass strengthening institutional governance for sustainable delivery of Primary Health Care for women and children amongst the vulnerable population in underserved areas, particularly in urban slums and newly included wards in city corporations and municipalities. The four expected outcomes are: 1. Health systems are strengthened through institutional reform with a functioning institutional structure and data management systems to improve accountability for delivery of efficient Primary Health Care (PHC);2. Innovative model of sustainable service delivery system is established to improve access to and utilization of PHC services especially by the poorest and vulnerable/segregated population ;3. Coverage of primary health care is improved in urban slum settlements and for socially segregated groups4. Evidence based on good practices and lessons learned is available for policy dialogue and advocacy to influence decision making processes

title.narrative: COVID-19 Strengthening Women’s Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO-II)
COVID-19 Strengthening Women’s Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO-II)

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Detta projekt syftar till att lyfta några av Bangladeshs fattigaste kvinnor, som lever på landsbygden i delar av landet som är särskilt utsatta för klimatförändringarnas negativa effekter, ut ur extrem fattigdom genom att dra nytta av produktiva inkomstmöjligheter. Den primära målgruppen är 3600 kvinnor i Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha och Jamalpur distrikten även om betydligt fler människor, inklusive dessa kvinnors barn, kommer att dra viss nytta av projektets positiva effekter.
SWAPNO-II syftar till att öka målgruppens inkomster och tillgångar genom att vidga deras valmöjligheter, öka deras kapacitet att göra val, stärka deras motståndskraft mot externa chocker, inklusive klimatrelaterade katastrofer och öka deras tillgång till finansiella tjänster samt se till att projektets fördelar kvarstår över tid.
Målen ska nås genom en kombination av ansträngningar. Kvinnorna anställs först i offentliga arbeten fora att återuppbygga eller klimatsäkra kritisk infrastruktur och för det arbetet får det en liten, men säker lön var fjortonde dag under ett halvår. En del av lönen sparas automatiskt och den delen får kvinnorna tillgång till som en större engångssumma vid anställningsperiodens slut. Meningen är att den ska möjliggöra för kvinnorna att starta sina egna småföretag. Kvinnorna får också utbildning i olika vardagskunskaper och lite yrkeskunskaper som är relevanta för att hitta anställning eller starta eget företag vilket ökar deras nätverk och personliga värdighet. Stöd ges också för tillgång till digitala finansiella tjänster och försäkringar. Idén är att kvinnornas ökade inkomster, kombinerat med ökade kunskaper och självsäkerhet ska hjälpa dem att investera på ett produktivt sätt som ger dem avkastning under kommande år. Dessutom bidar projektet till att öka de lokala myndigheternas kapacitet att implementera fattigdomsreducerande och genderkänsliga sociala transfereringssystem.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 This project aims at sustainably lifting some of Bangladesh’s poorest women, living in rural areas prone to the negative effects of climate change, of out of extreme poverty, primarily by making use of productive income-generating opportunities. The main beneficiaries are 3600 women in the districts of Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha and Jamalpur even if a substantially larger number of people, including these women’s children, will benefit, to various extents, from the positive effects of this project.
SWAPNO-II aims to increase the targeted women’s income and assets by expanding their choices, enhance their capabilities for exercising choices, strengthen their resilience to shocks, including disasters and climate change, and enhance their financial inclusion and ensure that the benefits are sustainable over time.
This will be achieved through a combination of efforts. The women will first be engaged in public-works to rehabilitate and/or climate proof critical local infrastructure for which they receive a small, predictable, fortnightly, salary during a period of six months. A part of the remuneration is set aside in compulsory savings which the women will access as a lump-sum at the end of the public-works period to allow them to, for example start their own small-scale businesses. They will also be trained in various life-skills as well as skills relevant for future employments, enhancing their networks and contributing to personal dignity. Assistance will also be provided to access digital financial services and insurance schemes. The idea is that their increased income combined with life and employability skills and enhance self-esteem will help beneficiaries invest productively to ensure a stream of income in years to come. Moreover, the capacity of the local government to implement pro-poor, gender-sensitive social-transfer projects will be enhanced.

The overall objective of SWAPNO-II is to lift some of the poorest women, living in areas most vulnerable to natural hazards, out of poverty and help them sustain higher income levels after the project period. More specifically, the project aims to: - Increase the income and assets the target women have, - Enhance the human capabilities of these women for exercising choices, - Strengthen their resilience to shocks, including those created by natural disasters and climate change, - Enhance the financial inclusion to provide these women with more equitable opportunities, and - Improve policies and mechanisms for sustaining the benefits of this project and broaden its reach. SWAPNO-II will make different contributions to the women included in the different phases. For those who have already been employed in SWAPNO-I, this new phase will contribute with some additional learning, a few activities and follow-up to ensure that the benefits are sustainable. However, for the 3600 new beneficiaries, SWAPNO-II is intended to provide all of the above-mentioned results.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

title.narrative: Sustainable Graduation from Exxtreme Poverty of SWAPNO Women Project-II

description.narrative: In 2020, SWAPNO-II completed its first activity period and this conclusion of performance covers the intended results achieved during the reporting period from September 2019 to August 2020 following the result chain, against the Result Resource Framework (RRF) of the contribution proposal. This Conclusion on Performance has been prepared based on the annual report 2020, reports on different studies and field visits conducted during December 2019. The project is working towards five specific outcomes and each outcome has specific outputs and intended results. The first annual report 2020 describes the progress in achieving either the outcomes or immediate results derived out of activities. During this period the contribution progress was satisfactory but due to global COVID pandemic and the Bangladesh Government imposed countrywide lockdown and movement restriction from March to June 2020, some of the field activities were disrupted/delayed. As of below a summary of progresses during the contribution’s first activity period: Outcome 1 “INCREASED INCOME AND ASSETS BY EXPANDING CHOICES” focuses on a public works-based poverty graduation approach where wage employment through public works is matched with training on market-based skills and access to productive employment supports women to move out of poverty. All the activities planned under this outcome for the first activity period was completed and most of the targets following the Result Resource Framework (RRF) of the project have been achieved. Under this outcome, the project has selected 3,564 eligible women (47 percent are widowed, 27 percent abandoned, 18 percent are either divorced or separated and 8 percent live with a disabled husband) from 99 UPs (Union Parishads) of 3 selected districts. During the reporting period, those women worked for 635,642 person days and earned BDT 10,490,400 (USD 1.24 million or 10.3 MSEK) in wages. The payment was made through a G2P (government to person) payment modality using mobile wallets, as to ensure that the mobile bank accounts and digital payments were exclusively belonging to the intended end-beneficiaries. The project also facilitated the formation of 297 Rotating Savings and Credit Associations (ROSCA) with the beneficiaries and within the reporting period where the saved amount by the ROSCA equaled to BDT 12,830,400. Project also helped beneficiaries with information and ideas about feasible livelihood opportunities within which they could invest their savings. Following this, around 81% beneficiaries have started different IGAs (Income Generating Activities) which are mostly on livestock rearing and small business within the reporting period. In addition, the project facilitated beneficiaries to startup kitchen gardens after building up their capacities to a certain level, using the acknowledged “sack method” (a climate resilient agriculture technology in flood prone areas). As an immediate action to diversify livelihoods during COVID-19 pandemic, the project in cooperation with the Ministry of Women and Children Affairs (MoWCA) trained beneficiaries to produce face masks. As an immediate result, around 67,500 facial masks were produced by the end of reporting period of which were sold at local markets to a value of BDT 1,485,000 (USD 17,575 or 145,565 SEK). Outcome 2 “ENHANCED HUMAN CAPABILITIES FOR EXERCISING CHOICES” focuses on the approach to enhance conditions to promote women’s empowerment. Under this outcome, the project has successfully completed the life skills training on seven selected modules following WHO recommended health safety measure for 100 percent of the beneficiaries. This intervention enabled beneficiaries to enhance knowledge and skills on health and nutrition, leadership, gender equality, basic rights and entitlement, climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction, and business and financial management. To improve the nutrition intake of beneficiaries and community people of targeted areas, the project organized different awareness campaigns and healthy cooking demonstration. As an immediate result, it was observed that around 52 percent of targeted beneficiaries adopted improved nutrition practices. Furthermore, the project has motivated beneficiaries to access local health care facilities for themselves and their family members, as well as establishing an effective working relationship with the Activating Village Court in Bangladesh (AVCB) project in Kurigram to create access to local justice systems for the women beneficiaries facing violence in the family, society and at work. Outcome 3 “STRENGTHENED RESILIENCE TO SHOCKS INCLUDING DISASTERS AND CLIMATE CHANGE” focuses on building the resilience of the women and their communities to climate change related shocks. Specifically, it has aligned with Sida support to another contribution (LoGIC), to establish and maintain coordination mechanisms, disaster risk reduction action plans and protect key public assets. Under this outcome, the project is piloting different entrepreneurship models for its beneficiaries, especially in agriculture sector, to enhance household production using adaptive technologies (hydroponic, vermicompost, etc.). In addition, the project already initiated mask production and low-cost sanitary napkins (Outcome 1). The project hired a national consultant to enhance existing coordination between LoGIC and SWAPNO in the field and to assess the level of coordination and interactions between the Union Disaster Management Committees (UDMCs) and the Standing Committees (SCs), to identify training needs and develop a training manual. The consultant will also come-up with types of climate adaptive livelihoods activities that could be undertaken to the benefit of the beneficiaries. Furthermore, SWAPNO enabled the UPs and the communities to select 5,986 key public assets through meeting and consultation for public work scheme and during the reporting period, 635,642 person days of work was completed by 3,564 women beneficiaries. Outcome 4 “ENHANCED FINANCIAL INCLUSION FOR EQUITABLE OPPORTUNITIES” focuses on promoting financial inclusion and the strengthening of the G2P (government-to-person) digital payment system. Under this outcome, the project distributed 3,564 mobile phones with SIM cards and opened mobile bank account with newly recruited beneficiaries in three districts. Beneficiaries were also provided with an orientation and training on mobile money transfer process by the local agents of mobile bank and union workers. As an immediate result, 100 percent of the beneficiaries started digital financial transactions through mobile wallets and mobile accounts, where they have received their wages for public work and COVID-19 grants along with other government support. The project has also undertaken a study on financial inclusion to collect baseline information on different aspects of financial inclusion including behavioral impact, user experiences with mobile money provider, savings habit, etc. (One of the findings of the study was that only 3 percent of the beneficiaries had access to digital financial service before joining the project.) Outcome 5 “IMPROVED POLICIES AND MECHANISMS FOR SUSTAINING BENEFITS” focuses on improving policies and strengthening local government capacity for sustaining SWAPNO II’s impacts and to support evidence-based research for promoting SWAPNO II’s approach. Under this outcome, the project has conducted some evidence-based research, studies, and meetings within the reporting time and most of the activities are planned for the following reporting period. From the very beginning of the COVID- 19 pandemic, SWAPNO took initiatives to raise awareness of the beneficiary households to avoid COVID-19 transmission by following the WHO advise. The project disseminated awareness raising messages, demonstration of hand washing, distribution of soap bars and facial masks among the beneficiaries. Since most of livelihoods of SWAPNO beneficiaries incurred loss for two months lock down, the project managed and delivered solidarity packages, food baskets and some cash grants for all beneficiaries from different internal and external sources.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Strengthening Women’s Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO-II)
COVID-19 Strengthening Women’s Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO-II)

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Detta projekt syftar till att lyfta några av Bangladeshs fattigaste kvinnor, som lever på landsbygden i delar av landet som är särskilt utsatta för klimatförändringarnas negativa effekter, ut ur extrem fattigdom genom att dra nytta av produktiva inkomstmöjligheter. Den primära målgruppen är 3600 kvinnor i Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha och Jamalpur distrikten även om betydligt fler människor, inklusive dessa kvinnors barn, kommer att dra viss nytta av projektets positiva effekter.
SWAPNO-II syftar till att öka målgruppens inkomster och tillgångar genom att vidga deras valmöjligheter, öka deras kapacitet att göra val, stärka deras motståndskraft mot externa chocker, inklusive klimatrelaterade katastrofer och öka deras tillgång till finansiella tjänster samt se till att projektets fördelar kvarstår över tid.
Målen ska nås genom en kombination av ansträngningar. Kvinnorna anställs först i offentliga arbeten fora att återuppbygga eller klimatsäkra kritisk infrastruktur och för det arbetet får det en liten, men säker lön var fjortonde dag under ett halvår. En del av lönen sparas automatiskt och den delen får kvinnorna tillgång till som en större engångssumma vid anställningsperiodens slut. Meningen är att den ska möjliggöra för kvinnorna att starta sina egna småföretag. Kvinnorna får också utbildning i olika vardagskunskaper och lite yrkeskunskaper som är relevanta för att hitta anställning eller starta eget företag vilket ökar deras nätverk och personliga värdighet. Stöd ges också för tillgång till digitala finansiella tjänster och försäkringar. Idén är att kvinnornas ökade inkomster, kombinerat med ökade kunskaper och självsäkerhet ska hjälpa dem att investera på ett produktivt sätt som ger dem avkastning under kommande år. Dessutom bidar projektet till att öka de lokala myndigheternas kapacitet att implementera fattigdomsreducerande och genderkänsliga sociala transfereringssystem.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 This project aims at sustainably lifting some of Bangladesh’s poorest women, living in rural areas prone to the negative effects of climate change, of out of extreme poverty, primarily by making use of productive income-generating opportunities. The main beneficiaries are 3600 women in the districts of Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha and Jamalpur even if a substantially larger number of people, including these women’s children, will benefit, to various extents, from the positive effects of this project.
SWAPNO-II aims to increase the targeted women’s income and assets by expanding their choices, enhance their capabilities for exercising choices, strengthen their resilience to shocks, including disasters and climate change, and enhance their financial inclusion and ensure that the benefits are sustainable over time.
This will be achieved through a combination of efforts. The women will first be engaged in public-works to rehabilitate and/or climate proof critical local infrastructure for which they receive a small, predictable, fortnightly, salary during a period of six months. A part of the remuneration is set aside in compulsory savings which the women will access as a lump-sum at the end of the public-works period to allow them to, for example start their own small-scale businesses. They will also be trained in various life-skills as well as skills relevant for future employments, enhancing their networks and contributing to personal dignity. Assistance will also be provided to access digital financial services and insurance schemes. The idea is that their increased income combined with life and employability skills and enhance self-esteem will help beneficiaries invest productively to ensure a stream of income in years to come. Moreover, the capacity of the local government to implement pro-poor, gender-sensitive social-transfer projects will be enhanced.

The overall objective of SWAPNO-II is to lift some of the poorest women, living in areas most vulnerable to natural hazards, out of poverty and help them sustain higher income levels after the project period. More specifically, the project aims to: - Increase the income and assets the target women have, - Enhance the human capabilities of these women for exercising choices, - Strengthen their resilience to shocks, including those created by natural disasters and climate change, - Enhance the financial inclusion to provide these women with more equitable opportunities, and - Improve policies and mechanisms for sustaining the benefits of this project and broaden its reach. SWAPNO-II will make different contributions to the women included in the different phases. For those who have already been employed in SWAPNO-I, this new phase will contribute with some additional learning, a few activities and follow-up to ensure that the benefits are sustainable. However, for the 3600 new beneficiaries, SWAPNO-II is intended to provide all of the above-mentioned results.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
